quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: World and Films
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, cartoon, books. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: If I were to visit the wrist-wrestling capital of the world, where would I go?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Petaluma, California.

questions.question: Who is Shreks sidekick in the films Shrek, Shrek 2, and Shrek the Third?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Donkey

questions.question: Which of the following are old time cartoon characters?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Mutt and Jeff

questions.question: Which of these Disney characters go together?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: What are the Latin terms that refer to plant and animal life?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: flora and fauna

questions.question: What was the original name of the melodramatic musical, West Side Story?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: East Side Story

questions.question: Which of these great books was first published in 1771?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Encyclopedia Britannica

questions.question: Which word goes with the Oriental symbol Yang?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Yin

questions.question: Whose real name was Leonard Sly?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Roy Rogers

questions.question: Where is the Henry Ford museum located?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Greenfield Village

questions.question: Who is Harry Potters best friend and schoolmate?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Ron Weasley

questions.question: The student Rosencrantz is coupled with what fellow student?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Guildenstern

questions.question: Who were the legendary founders of  the city of Rome?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Romulus and Remus

questions.question: Who was Nero Wolfs legman and confidant?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Archie Goodwin

questions.question: Which is the only US state to have two Ivy League colleges in it ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: New York

quizzes.title: History Quiz: Word and Type
quizzes.description: Test your history knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering History, period, language. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Orange River is the longest river in which country?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Republic of South Africa

questions.question: There is no word in the English language that rhymes with orange.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: Name the two famous streets that were the heart of the hippie movement.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Haight and Ashbury

questions.question: What type of insect is the Orange Tip?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Butterfly

questions.question: What two colors are mixed together to get orange?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Red and yellow

questions.question: This 7-year-old pilot trainee died in her attempt to become the youngest person to fly a plane across the United States.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jessica Dubroff

questions.question: Which word refers to a specialized type of building in a garden that is used for the growing of citrus trees?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Orangery

questions.question: This word refers to the ancient art of aerodynamically stabilizing arrows from materials, such as feathers or modern plastics.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fletching

questions.question: Suleiman the Magnificent personally led Ottoman armies to conquer Belgrade, Rhodes, and most of Hungary.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: What is the name of the essential oil made from the blossom of the bitter orange?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Neroli

questions.question: Which famous painter, a representative of the romantic period, delivered the following words: Artists who seek perfection in everything are those who cannot attain it in anything.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Delacroix

questions.question: In what year did Stanley Kubrick direct his Oscar-nominated film A Clockwork Orange?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1971

questions.question: In 1927 Austrian baker and confectioner, Eduard Haas invented what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: PEZ candy

questions.question: Orange Pekoe is a type of what?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tea

questions.question: What was the nationality of William III of England who was often called William of Orange?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dutch

quizzes.title: Geography Quiz: Award and Maryland
quizzes.description: Test your geography knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Geography, john, sergeant. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This Chinese city, the capital of Hubei province, lies at the confluence of the Yangtze River and Han River.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Wuhan

questions.question: What do American Presidents John Quincy Adams, Rutherford B. Hayes, Benjamin Harrison and George W. Bush all have in common?

options.text: They won the electoral vote but not the popular vote.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They won the electoral vote but not the popular vote.

questions.question: This island, which is a French territory, is located in the Indian Ocean, east of Madagascar, about 200 km southwest of Mauritius.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Reunion

questions.question: This prion disease is also known as laughing sickness due to the outbursts of laughter that mark its second phase.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Kuru

questions.question: This 1968 song, recorded by the Beatles, was written by Paul McCartney, who wanted to cheer up Lennons son, Julian.

options.text: Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Hey Jude

questions.question: In what year did President Franklin Roosevelt give the approval for dropping the first atom bomb on Japan?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: He never did

questions.question: What award was given to President George W. Bush in 2004?

options.text: The Raspberry Award for worst leading actor
The Hendley Award for Great Americans

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Raspberry Award for worst leading actor

questions.question: This US President granted a posthumous pardon to Robert Edward Lee, a general of the Confederate forces during the American Civil War.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gerald Ford

questions.question: Gunnery sergeant John Basilone of the US Marine Corps, was awarded the Medal of Honor for what reason?

options.text: Outstanding heroism during the attack on Pearl Harbour
Outstanding heroism during the Vietnam War
Outstanding heroism at Guadalcanal during World War II
Outstanding heroism during the Gulf Wars

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Outstanding heroism at Guadalcanal during World War II

questions.question: The world-class hospital in Maryland was named after a person whose last name was Hopkins. What was his first name?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johns

questions.question: What city, nicknamed The Mile-High City, is located on the plains east of the Rocky Mountains?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Denver, Colorado

questions.question: This movie, directed by Bo Welch, won the 2003 Raspberry award in the category, Worst Excuse for an Actual Movie.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Cat in the Hat

questions.question: The Warren Commission, was established on November 29, 1963 by Lyndon B. Johnson to investigate what?

options.text: The assassination of John F. Kennedy

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The assassination of John F. Kennedy

questions.question: This annual plant, also called brinjal, is native to southern India and Sri Lanka.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Eggplant

questions.question: In 2004, this famous show business family became the second clan to have three generations of Oscar winners.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: The Coppolas

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Following and Letters
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, table, following. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: Which of the following are well known English puppets?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Punch and Judy

questions.question: Regardless of its size, approximately this much of an iceberg is visible above the waterline.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1/9

questions.question: Which of the following are among the top female comedy writers in British television?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saunders and French

questions.question: Teams in the NHL and the NBA both usually play this many regular season games.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 82

questions.question: Who were the star-crossed lovers from West Side Story ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Tony and Maria

questions.question: Which of these is the name of the company that manufactures several first aid remedies?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Johnson and Johnson

questions.question: Over the course of the complete works of William Shakespeare, the bard uses this many different words.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 29,066

questions.question: Before making the change to a decimal based monetary system, one English guinea was comprised of this many shillings.  Coincidentally, it is also the number of letters in the Italian alphabet.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 21

questions.question: Which of the following are usually part of every restaurant table setting?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Salt and pepper

questions.question: In the game of Scrabble, if a player uses all seven of their letters in a turn, they receive a bonus of how many points?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 50

questions.question: Complete the name of the American printmaking firm that produced prints by hand-colored lithography: ........... and Ives.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Currier

questions.question: Which of these comedy teams consists of a husband and wife, whose son is an Emmy Award-winning actor?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Stiller and Meara

questions.question: Which of the following were an old-time radio duo?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: All of these

questions.question: Who were the two teenagers who were transported into various time periods in a series of movies?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Bill and Ted

questions.question: In the U.S., the maximum term of an issued patent is this many years, from the earliest claimed filing date.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 20

quizzes.title: Entertainment Quiz: Book and Price
quizzes.description: Test your entertainment knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Entertainment, blues, phillips. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: This tall actress is famous for her portrayal of Ripley in the film Alien.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Sigourney Weaver

questions.question: During the reign of George III, this British politician held the position of Prime Minister from 1783 to 1801, and again from 1804 until his death.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Pitt the Younger

questions.question: Solve for X:
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 0

questions.question: At the end of his historic performance at the Monterey Pop Festival in 1967, this musician set his guitar Fender Stratocaster on fire.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Jimi Hendrix

questions.question: This rhythm and blues song from 1951 is claimed by the owner of Sun Records, Sam Phillips, to be the first rock and roll song.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Rocket 88

questions.question: This Greek word, used in Homers works, means virtue or being the best you can be.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Arete

questions.question: This author wrote a book in which the story is told from the view poin of the mulatto slave Cynara, born on the plantation Tata.  The book is a parody of  the novel Gone with the Wind.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Alice Randall

questions.question: What term derives from a Latin word meaning rods bundled around an axe ?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fascism

questions.question: The top price for a ticket to the Super Bowl I in 1967.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: $12

questions.question: Alban W. Phillips is the discoverer of the Phillips Curve. What does this curve show?

options.text: Inflation is inversely proportional to unemployment.
Property is the real basis for wealth in a capitalistic society.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Inflation is inversely proportional to unemployment.

questions.question: Homers epic poems, The Iliad and The Odyssey, are made up of this many books each.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 24

questions.question: The number of weeks the Barenaked Ladies hit, One Week was #1 on the U.S. Billboard pop chart in 1998.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1

questions.question: In 1839, while spending the winter with George Sand in Majorca, this composer completed a work  consisting of 24 short preludes. Each prelude was in a different major or minor key.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Chopin

questions.question: What American state, known also as the Silver State, is named after a weather condition?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Nevada

questions.question: In what year did Nicolas Cugnot invent the first successful steam-powered road vehicle?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1769

quizzes.title: Literature Quiz: Year and Organization
quizzes.description: Test your literature knowledge with this comprehensive quiz! Features 15 questions covering Literature, bach, steve. Includes 5 easy, 5 medium, and 5 challenging questions. Can you achieve a passing score of 70%?

questions.question: The Virginia General Assembly was founded in Jamestown in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1619

questions.question: Which list contains four of the five basic ballet moves?

options.text: Pirouette, Arabesque, Pas des deux, Grande cabriole

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Fouette, Attitude, Pirouette, Arabesque

questions.question: What is true about all objects that emit heat?

options.text: They are all composed of plasmas.

questions.explanation: The correct answer is: They all emit infra-red waves.

questions.question: SMERSH, the organization mentioned in the James Bond film, From Russia with Love, was a real Russian organization.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: True

questions.question: The USA owns a territory in the Pacific called  The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. What is its capital city?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Saipan

questions.question: What did  Wilhelm Schickard invent?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the first automatic calculator

questions.question: According to a study published in the Annals of Neurology, people who regularly come into contact with pesticides are 70 % more likely to develop what disease?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Parkinsons disease

questions.question: What was the last name of Italian brothers Carlo, Bindo, Alfieri, Ettore, and Ernesto who were all in the automobile business?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Maserati

questions.question: The dram is the monetary unit of this country whose capital city is Yerevan.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Armenia

questions.question: This city state, also called Ragusa, was first to recognize the independence of the newly formed United States of America.
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Dubrovnik

questions.question: Which is the correct definition for oxter?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: the armpit

questions.question: Handel, Bach and  Scarlatti were all born in what year?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: 1685

questions.question: The Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki are the sacred texts of which religion?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Shinto

questions.question: Which of these books was not  written by Steve Allen?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Murder in the Valley

questions.question: What was the currency of the Netherlands, before the adoption of the euro?
questions.explanation: The correct answer is: Gulden
